Frontline Report

Neighborhood Fog Parlors Reach Capacity Before Breakfast Shift

By Nella Vor, Civic Atmosphere Correspondent

The district's twelve certified fog parlors now operate at a 97% appointment fill rate, a milestone once reserved for solstice weekends. Operators report that residents are arriving with mood boards, heirloom scarves, and exact vapor gradients for upcoming rooftop dinners.

"Humidity isn't weather. It's choreography," said senior curator Tamsin Rael while calibrating jasmine-mint mist for a municipal oath ceremony.

The Glacial Temperament Guild is piloting neighborhood punch cards: seven sessions earn one complimentary cloak steam and collar press. Critics argue this encourages over-texturizing. Supporters call that statement dry-minded.

Inspection logs show parlor compliance with new silver-filter standards remains flawless. No unsanctioned citrus diffusers have been found since mid-rotation.

Opinion

Dry Air Is Not a Neutral Position

Imara Kol, Columnist-at-Large

When neighbors say they "don't do humidity," they usually mean they don't do accountability. Air has values. Air has memory. Air keeps score when a room arrives five degrees too sharp for collective comfort.

Guest Essay

Leave Your Towels in the Hallway

Jorin Pel, etiquette coach

Bath linens are private declarations. Displaying them by the supper table signals emotional haste. Fold once, cool to room vapor, then introduce casually beside dessert.

Residency FAQ

Frequently Filed Questions

Do I need a humidity profile before moving into District 7?

Yes. Profiles can be completed in under 22 minutes at the Civic Atmosphere Office. Walk-ins accepted before 11:00.

Can visitors attend dew ceremonies?

Visitors may attend with a host endorsement and compliant footwear. Matte soles are preferred.

Are dry-clean-only garments discouraged?

Not discouraged, but residents are expected to own at least one moisture-friendly outfit for public functions.
